movement I thought that time would

you first enter the legal profession did

during the Cultural Revolution my
parents were sent to the countryside and
I lived with my brother in Beijing
finally I got to University in 1981 I
knew the Nobel Peace Prize winner new
cowboy and the famous human rights law
Bujji Chang while I was at university we
argued all the time but we also
influenced each other now they are both
in prison how does it feel to see your
old friends your old colleagues behind
bars and for you to step in to have to
defend them what they did hominin I'll
try my best to defend them even though
it's not easy given that China's
judicial system is not fully independent
I also respect them for what they did
expressing their opinions and keeping
their faith regardless of the
possibility that they might go to jail
we've seen many lawyers targeted in the

da da farted wah wah China has
definitely showed progress when it comes

two sets of laws one constitutional law
at one marriage law we now have about
two hundred biggest problem now is that
the law isn't respected and implemented
especially in connection with people and
organizations with state power they
break laws knowingly and rampantly but
they're not punished for it in other
words China has laws but no rule of law
we have a constitution but no
constitutional governance it's the same
thing with human rights we've made a lot
of progress in
fighting people with food and shelter
when we were young eating bread was a

a good life but we have severe problems

you know what keeps you going when when
